body:
From a user point of view it would be great if native notifications would be automatically used when the main window is minimized or not in focus. I don't know if this is feasible or not.

Think of this: launch a lenghty compilation, switch to the browser to look at something, native notification popping up to warn build complete.

I wouldn't mind if a first implementation does not have link clicking support, those notifications usually happen with the main window in focus.

I would add a simple darker border anyway. It would be more consistent with the icons on the toolbar: they all have dark outlines. Besides I would keep the "cheap" shadow as an option (dark outline 1 pixel down): it makes the text more readable on the yellowish part for example. I would definitely get rid off the grid.

hello,  I use NetBeans 11.3-beta3 in Windows 10 OS and find that progress bar leaves vertical stripes during scrolling. But I am not sure whether it is common phenomenon.
Here are pictures(All in FlatLaf Look and Feel): 
![blue stripe](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/52394598/75025452-30ff6580-54d6-11ea-99dc-5d5e98bf5bdf.png)
![blue stripe  light](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/52394598/75025671-8fc4df00-54d6-11ea-8768-c9f8963af6be.png)
![big progress bar light](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/52394598/75025865-e6cab400-54d6-11ea-810c-31fe826e2fbd.png)

NetBeans 11.3-beta3 "Open Project" Dialog changes directory names in "directory" bar in Windows 10. 

NetBeans 11.2:
![11 2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/52394598/75030374-edf5c000-54de-11ea-924e-0d76763eebf2.png)
All directory name are in system default language.

but now:
![11 3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/52394598/75030357-e7ffdf00-54de-11ea-90d1-8acf56cd7dbd.png)
"Recent"、“Desktop”、"Documents" are in English, while the other two are in system default language.

I think it would be better to show those directory names in the same language.
@humphreygao would you be so kind and check whether these texts are correct in Windows L&F and Metal L&F (in NB 11.3)?

Is the issue solved on the VC2, the artefacts are here https://builds.apache.org/view/M-R/view/NetBeans/job/netbeans-TLP/job/netbeans/job/release113/20/artifact/dist/netbeans/11.3/vc2/

Would be to know if ok for you.

@ebarboni both source and binary look sane to me. Thank you.

@jlahoda thank you for your input. I pushed an update, that tries to implement the suggested changes.  For applyTestEdits I decided to use the simple variant (start and end index instead of a BiPredicate) - I have not a clear vision where a more complex predicate than the start and end filter could be needed. As the function is purely used internally we can still evolve it it if necessary.
Removing build warnings is an "honorable cause"; thank you!

In this one there's a lot of formatting changes unrelated to the subject of the bug/description.

It's best to avoid making formatting changes for their own sake, except when the code is being changed in any case. Formatting changes make merges more difficult and clutters git history, e.g. when doing "git blame".

@eirikbakke can you please revert. 
Would be nice to wait until vote is finished and a few mandatory commit are done then will I, will tell dev list that we can merge again.
Oh, sorry--didn't realize merges here impacted the ongoing release. Feel free to revert.
Or I can revert myself, hold on...
Revert done. Sorry about that.

Oh, now I see that github has it's own "Revert" button here. I did it manually through the command-line client, so the revert won't show up on this PR. I'll have to remember to reapply this PR at a later date, after the release stuff is done.

@junichi11 thank you - you are right, the version increment is required by the parsing API and the changes in the test file should have not been there. I added another commit, that fixes these issues.

Thank you @junichi11 I tested the test and indeed it fails without the fix and works with it. I looks sane to me, so I took the liberty to include it. I rebased the PR, so that it reassembles the patches in the order I would like to see them in the repository and the authorship is correctly attributed.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1915443/75103461-238fcb80-55fb-11ea-841d-5da035df2bc3.png)

Thanks Mathias for your very prompt response. Of course, I'm aware that I am donating this code to the ASF, it's my pleasure to be able to contribute in such a big community.

I tested this fix with current version of MySQL v8.0.19 and with old database v5.5.8 from 2010. and it works fine.

@sbrbot my request boils down to this: It is easier to merge a PR if it does not raise discussions. @junichi11 and I most probably don't agree on everything, but if your PR does not touch areas it does not need to touch it will get approval easier. In this case changing the choise of words or removing NO18N markers does nothing to help the PR.

The same goes for the change to the Oracle statements. It is well possible, that the DB treats the statement case sensitive, then your change introduces a regression. The point is: I did not test on Oracle DB and my reading is, that you did neither, so it would be better to keep the case as-is.
Only MacOs tests failed and that's because of missing `ant` (!?)
What is the motivation for this fix? From the fix I guess, that you observed an IndexOutOfBoundExceptions? It would be helpful to have test case for this then.
@sbrbot  there is no update - did you forget to push?

Please check your settings for the name - it currently reads (namnull). You can check it with the commandline client. Run `git log -n 1` while the NETBEANS-3903 branch is checked out. 

The commit message in general is ok, however  it is customary to leave an empty line between the summary (firstline) and the description (the other lines). Messages should also be wrapped to a maximum of 72 characters per line.

I came across this while reading code
1) this clearly does not do what is advertised in comment
2) yet there will be no IndexOutOfBounds (or any other Exception) because `release()` checks bounds on entry and than in a loop (it just fails to remove half of elements)
3) Antlr's charstream definies `mark()` as (from their
javadoc):
.
> A mark provides a guarantee that seek() operations will be valid over
a "marked range" extending from the index where mark() was called to the
current index().

[..]

> The returned mark is an opaque handle (type int) which is passed to
release() when the guarantees provided by the marked range are no longer
necessary. When calls to mark()/release() are nested, the marks must be
released in reverse order of which they were obtained

and `release()`:
>This method releases a marked range created by a call to mark(). Calls
to release() must appear in the reverse order of the corresponding calls
to mark(). If a mark is released twice, or if marks are not released in
reverse order of the corresponding calls to mark(), the behavior is
unspecified.

assuming that, calling `release()` with latest index will always remove latest element - so it's safe anyway. However this loop and comment suggest that author seemed to practice defensive development (and/or antr's) could be different in older versions (but than, that is a memory leak, these marks would stay there until class gets GCed) - so if we are about to leave that code, it should rather do what it is supposed to. 
4) there are no other usages of that `markers` in code, and seek() seems to assume that it can freely move around, so it's probably also safe to change `mark()` code to return -1 and then leave `release()` empty, the same way it is done here:
https://github.com/antlr/antlr4/blob/38b1b9ac7f602ee5b0013edb0cc589b10019c318/runtime/Java/src/org/antlr/v4/runtime/CodePointCharStream.java#L111-L119 (but again, are there any test to cover that?)
thks for the review. Merging

> I have no problem if you prefer to discuss this on the mailing list and wait to continue developing this or not when the mailing list get a decision.

I think the need for an extended discussion occurs primarily when it comes to changing the _default_ behavior. If it's just something that interested users can enable in the Options dialog, then the stakes are much lower, and it also allows improvements to be made gradually without implementing everything at once (MacOS support etc.).

You can add more commits to this Pull Request by pushing to the same branch. Alternatively, you can amend the commit and force-push to the same branch. Then the diff will update here.

(This is how these Pull Requests usually go--people request changes, the original submitter pushes additional commits or force-pushed amendments, etc., until everybody is happy. In the end, the chain of commits in the PR is usually "squashed" by GitHub into a single, clean commit that goes onto the NetBeans master branch.)
Yup! Squashed and merged.
Thank you--done!

The latest version of JAVA EE 8 is 8.0.1 which was released a year and a half later than 8.0. This was the latest revision that oracle did before donating the project to the Eclipse Foundation.

Some jars update their dependencies like JUnit, some have bug fixes and enhancements and some update their pom to reference the github where the source code is.

`j2ee.platform` is the javadoc that NetBeans create for JAVAEE, currently javaee7 instead of javaee8.
`web.jsf.editor` is the javadoc that NetBeans create for JSF, currently JSF 2.0 instead of JSF 2.3
shouldn't we update spec versions in formerly-friend modules to enforce the module update ?

@pepness thank you for the reply. The javadoc updates look sensible to me, the update of patch releases alo. What I meant were these updates:

- javax.security.jacc-api from 1.5 to 1.6
- javax.enterprise.concurrent-api from 1.0 to 1.1
- javax.enterprise.deploy-api from 1.6 to 1.7

do these belong to JavaEE 8 and is the version documented there or are they loosely coupled? In the context of the java ee this triggered my reply:

- jaxws-api from 2.2.8 to 2.3.1

I read this as a feature release and not a pure patch release, so does 2.3 belong to java ee 6?

Maybe it's possible to split the PR to hve one with 4.4 and another with archetype.

I think it would be nice to detect the most recent nbm/archetype instead of hardcoding.
I filed a second issue, [NETBEANS-3918], which is about spurious directory creation. I'll check to see which, if any, of those issues might include the problem in [NETBEANS-3875]

Sorry I realize that the description does not match this PR and after reading the JAVA EE 6 Specification I realize that there are mistakes with the required versions that are bundled in NetBeans and in my PR (like Commons Annotations). I will fix it. 

Thanks for the observations @matthiasblaesing

I check the [JAVA EE 6 Spec](https://jcp.org/en/jsr/detail?id=316), [JAVA EE 7 Spec](https://jcp.org/en/jsr/detail?id=342) and [JAVA EE 8 Spec](https://github.com/javaee/javaee-spec/blob/master/download/JavaEE8_Platform_Spec_FinalRelease.pdf) and find that:
- JAX-WS 2.1 for JEE 6
- JAX-WS 2.2 for JEE 7
- JAX-WS 2.3 for JEE 8

But I do not update that jar in this PR or the javaee 6 PR(I got the description wrong). For the others there where just changes in minor details mostly preparing the donation to the Eclipse Fundation:

- javax.enterprise.concurrent-api 
-- update the pom to reference the github where the source code is and the JUnit dependency
-- update the location of the license
-- update the copyright 

- avax.security.jacc-api
-- update the pom to reference the github where the source code is
-- update the location of the license
-- update the copyright 

- javax.enterprise.deploy-api
-- update the pom to reference the github where the source code is and some plugins
-- update the location of the license
-- update the copyright
I updated the description to reference the JAVA EE 8 Specification.

I know: http://wiki.apidesign.org/wiki/FriendDependencies - however I guess in this situation (E.g. when opening to public) it is not necessary. The formerly friend modules will work with old as well as new version of jumpto - new modules of course have to use the latest version.
Thank you.
Thank you.

I revisited this and reread the change in `NetworkProxyReloader.java` I don't think it is right. The message in default reads:

> System network proxy: fell to default (correct if direct mode went before)

So the fallthrough here is intentional. This `break` must not be inserted.

The whole changeset needs to be rebased onto master to be mergeable.

I suspect that other file types are affected too. The approach I chose might also be interesting for other cases where services should not be registered on the empty mime path.

New commit should be close. In the comment for setTargetFolder(Supplier) I had following, but seemed to much, took it out ``` * If TemplateWizard.getTargetFolder() is called and * the target folder is not set then invoke folderCreator * to create the directory and DataFolder. ``` Do you know someplace in the regular NetBeans code where I can use this and see it working in a non-test situation? Did not error check that both version of setTargetFolder are used, or other weird cases. Seemed like overkill. A little unclear about apichanges "compatibility". Since no differences if don't use new method, assume binary and source compatible. Not sure what modification means.

```
/home/travis/build/apache/netbeans/ide/projectuiapi/src/org/netbeans/spi/project/ui/templates/support/Templates.java:152: error: reference to setTargetFolder is ambiguous
   [repeat]                 ((TemplateWizard)wizardDescriptor).setTargetFolder( null );
```
Ambiguous reference. To stay compatible, I can change the new method to unique name like
`setLazyTargetFolder(Supplier)`
Comment?

Actually, I like
`setTargetFolderLazy(Supplier)`
better. You would see both methods together in code completion.
Excellent! The last remaining thing: the java/maven module has to depend on 7.76 version of opening.loaders now, otherwise it will not link. Then the change can be merged.
If you're up to it, there's an almost trivial change PR#1980 which would finish up the obvious/glaring problems with maven project creation.

> @jlahoda or @lahodaj as the 12.0 merge window is open, can you review the changes?

Currently, without nb-javac, refactoring run file-by-file (one javac instance per file), which increases chances it fits into the memory. This patch changes that to one javac instance for all files in the refactoring - that significantly improves the speed, but lowers the chances the processing will fit into the memory. I still think a middle ground - try to fit all into the memory, and run fast if it fits, but fallback to file-by-file processing if it doesn't - is the best combination. And, unless I am mistaken, this patch does not provide that.
Looks sane to me. Thank you.

I had another look at this today (github does not notify when you push updates!), what I noticed:
- history is still not linear. At this point I suggest to either redo the changes cleanly or do a full rebase with squashing of this PR, so that it becomes reviewable again. (if you need advise, please ask on the dev  mailinglist)
- `ide/db.metadata.model/src/org/netbeans/modules/db/metadata/model/resources/Bundle.properties` changes line endings. Please revert.
- `ide/db/libsrc/org/netbeans/lib/ddl/impl/ProcedureArgument.java` contains unnecessary changes (only formatting). Please revert.
- ` ide/db/src/org/netbeans/modules/db/explorer/node/ProcedureListNode.java` contains only whitepace changes. Please revert.
- The parameters subquery in `ProcedureNode.java` that returns `routine_params` looks like it would need an order by (else the server is free to reorder)
- There are still changes in the oracle code in `ProcedureNode.java`, the same is true for `ProcedureNodeProvider.java`

@dmochalov thank you - looks sane to me. Yes, please squash the commits, in theory github can do this when merging, but that requires the accounts from which the commits were created, to have public real name and email.
